III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
1

Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation When youth resided at the facility in 2022-2023, youth saw a
camera and a camera flash when she was changing in her room.
Somehow someone got on campus. There are trap houses on
either side of the facility, and everyone knows not to change in
their rooms. Sometimes the guards would leave the gate
unattended, and people, not staff, could get in. You could get
arrested if you got caught but that didn't stop people. There are
some places at the facility to hide in your room to change, but in
some rooms, there are wide open windows. Youth saw camera
flashes and her blinds were closed.
Investigation Interviews:
On 07/15/2024 attempts were made to contact the Complainant
about additional concerns without success.
On 07/16/2024 an onsite visit was completed at Vista Maria and
Consumer Rights Officer was interviewed. He was advised of
the allegations and confirmed that Youth A was placed at the
facility from February 2022 to April 2024. Consumer Rights
Officer advised that the agency does not have cameras in the
youth bedrooms. Copies of privacy and security policy were
provided for review.
On 07/16/2024 a telephone call was made to the Foster Care
Worker of Youth A. A message was left advising of involvement of
Youth A in the investigation and requesting a return call with any
additional information or concerns.
All of the following interviews took place on 8/07/2024 at Vista
Maria.
Youth B, Youth C and Youth D all denied seeing flashing lights or
cameras outside of their rooms. They denied that they feel like
people are watching them in their rooms and denied that they are
allowed to change their clothes in their rooms. They also all denied
seeing random individuals walking around on the campus of Vista
Maria and denied ever seeing the security gate open and
unsecured.
2

Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3 were all interviewed on site at Vista
Maria. All three denied ever seeing random individuals walking the
campus of Vista Maria or hearing youth complain about seeing
flashing lights outside of their bedroom windows. All three staff also
reported that the security gate at the agency is always operative
and they have never seen it unsecured or not manned by the
security staff.
Director of Security was interviewed. She denied that the security
staff has ever received any complaints or concerns regarding
flashing lights being seen outside the rooms of the youth or
complaints regarding random individuals walking around the
campus. Director of Security reported the only comments she has
heard is relative to the security at Vista Maria being too thorough.
She denied being aware of any breech and reported that the agency
has cameras that are monitored 24/7 and no concerns have been
seen.
On 09/19/2024 an email correspondence was sent to Foster Care
Worker requesting assistance in coordinating an interview with
Youth A.
On 09/20/2024 a video interview was completed with Youth A. She
recalled being placed at Vista Maria and reported leaving in April
2024. Youth A reported that while placed at Vista Maria she saw
flashing lights outside of her window. She reported telling staff, but
stated that they responded, “that’s why you should not change in
your room”. Youth A denied recalling which staff she reported it to.
Youth A also denied recalling any youth that would have been
present and witnessed the flashing lights outside of the bedroom
windows. Youth A denied seeing random individuals walking on the
campus. She reported that other youth would say that they saw
people on the campus that did not belong. Youth A could not recall
the names of any of the youth. She also reported that staff would
tell the residents that the community surrounding Vista Maria was
scary and had “trap houses” with people waiting outside the gates.
Youth A denied recalling the names of staff that would say this and
indicated that she believed the staff would say this to deter
residents from going AWOL.
Documents Reviewed:
Vista Maria Client Privacy Policy – Policy indicates Vista Maria
has established guidelines to ensure that client privacy is
preserved and protected. The following conventions are to be
observed in daily unit operations: 1. Male staff must always
announce when they are entering a sleeping or bathroom area.
3

2. Staff must knock on a client’s door before entering their room.
3. No doors will be removed (taken from their hinges) from
sleeping wing areas and bathrooms unless there is a clear, clinical
justification in writing and approved by the Program Manager.
Contraband searches.
Vista Maria Authorized Gate Entry/Campus Access Policy –
Policy indicates in order to maintain appropriate levels of safety
and security for clients, personnel, and visitors, Vista Maria
requires proper identification from all employees, visitors, and
vendors. Vista Maria ensures a safe, secure campus for the youth
and families served as well as for staff, visitors, volunteers and
contractors. Safety is an integral part of our culture.
Agency Tour: A tour of the facility was completed. Specifically,
the bedroom area of Beata Hall (where Youth A was housed),
gated entrance and exit area and general facility grounds were
toured. No areas of concern were noted and no random
individuals were seen on the campus of Vista Maria.
Analysis The agency is found to be in compliance with the licensing rules.
After completing interviews with youth, staff and security there
was no evidence to support non-compliance with the licensing
rules.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
